awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mental Health Opportunities for Professional Empowerment in STEM (HOPES)
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Science Foundation Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) award to Montana Technological University, Montana State University-Billings, and the University of Montana will develop and test a suite of innovative strategies to improve the mental health and resilience of graduate students in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). To accomplish this goal, the project includes interventions for both graduate students and the faculty mentors with whom they work closely, and it seeks to help transform the cultures of the departments to become more supportive and inclusive. This project addresses a gap in proven approaches to help graduate students manage the significant mental and emotional stresses and pressures they face. Counseling available on campuses mostly is designed for undergraduates, and little is known about how to empower STEM graduate students to cope with the stresses of their challenging research projects; overcome stigma, self doubt, and social isolation; and promote help-seeking and a sense of belonging. The situation is even tougher for women and minority students, veterans, students with disabilities, and students from disadvantaged backgrounds. Improving the well-being of diverse graduate students will boost their prospects for successful STEM careers – thereby accelerating science and engineering progress and contributing to American economic growth and competitiveness. 

The project goal is to design and pilot an innovative model for fostering graduate students’ life-long skills for mental health awareness and well-being, while transforming the way faculty engage with graduate students. The first step will be to conduct baseline surveys of students and faculty to obtain information needed to prioritize and design educational interventions. Project components will include: 1) activities to reduce stigma; 2) facilitated psychoeducational peer mentoring to assist students in developing effective coping strategies and enhanced resilience; 3) STEM faculty workshops aimed at implementing holistic mentoring, enhancing inclusiveness, and transforming departmental climates; and 4) activities engaging advisors and advisees together in collaborative problem solving. After refining the approach and demonstrating effectiveness on the three campuses, the team will assist three other universities in adapting the approaches to demonstrate scale up. Overall, the project will establish an innovative, effective, and replicable model for improving STEM graduate education by elevating positive mental health to an important outcome. Evaluation feedback will help improve the activities and measure progress toward achievement of the goal. Activity descriptions, facilitator guides, curricula, and scale-up guides will be published and disseminated.

This project is jointly funded by the IGE program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR). The Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) program is focused on research in graduate education. The goals of IGE are to pilot, test, and validate innovative approaches to graduate education and to generate the knowledge required to move these approaches into the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Graduate study in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) is known to be stressful, and each student’s relationship with their faculty advisor has a strong influence on their mental health. The Mental Health Opportunities for Professional Empowerment in STEM (M-HOPES) project studied strategies to support graduate-student mental health. Montana State University Billings (MSUB), Montana Technological University (MTech), and the University of Montana (UM) collaborated on M-HOPES. Informed by research on psychosocial interventions and best practices in mentoring, as well as guidance from students and faculty, we designed a holistic-mentoring workshop for faculty members, along with activities to help students develop resilience and skills to deal with the stresses and challenges of STEM graduate study. Student activities included counseling support groups, “happiness workshops” on how to apply positive psychology to their lives, and sessions on Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) skills.

 

Intellectual Merit: We surveyed graduate students and faculty in 2021, 2022, and 2023-24, learning about stressors, physical and mental health, experiences in graduate school, professional-development needs, challenges that would benefit from campus assistance, and advice for faculty. Survey responses revealed that student concerns about finances and the rising cost of living are strongly associated with negative mental health. Compared with students in non-STEM programs, STEM students felt more like impostors and were more reluctant to seek help for mental health challenges. The graduate students reported that the kinds of mental-health support they need were not well served by campus services. These services are designed for undergraduates, most of whom are younger, single, without dependents, and living away from their parents for the first time—a profile different from most graduate students. Sexual and gender minority (SGM) graduate students have similar academic experiences to non-SGM students, but they are more likely to have Impostor Syndrome and experience symptoms of depression and physical health concerns.

 

Faculty survey respondents, many of whom reported previously referring a student for mental-health assistance, were aware that students faced significant stressors. The faculty desired skills to mentor diverse graduate students effectively. M-HOPES holistic mentoring workshop series connected faculty with local mental-health resources, increased their awareness of signs and symptoms of mental-health struggles, and provided strategies for tailoring mentoring to the needs of individual students. UMOnline converted these workshops to professional quality, fully online modules for the Canvasâ platform, which substantially expands the potential impact.

 

To find out if the M-HOPES interventions would apply nationally we helped four other campuses adapt and deploy M-HOPES activities of interest to them. The campus that tried all the activities concluded that M-HOPES has significantly improved its institutional understanding of the graduate student population. It has added the M-HOPES counseling support groups to its support offerings and has updated its mental health seminar series to include topics based on M-HOPES data.

 

Participation in M-HOPES’ pilot activities was too low to prove the benefits. However, graduate students who attended the activities valued the skills they learned for overcoming stressors and for improving communication with faculty mentors. They also made useful connections with graduate-student peers in other degree programs. Faculty attendees appreciated the holistic mentoring skills and strategies emphasized in the workshops. The research team continues to analyze M-HOPES data and is preparing several articles for publication. 

 

Broader Impacts:  When STEM graduate study at the master's and doctoral levels becomes humane and supportive of positive mental health for both faculty and graduate students, it is likely that STEM fields will attract a broader range of people and more will persist to complete their degrees and join the STEM workforce. In turn, a supportive environment would foster mentoring that is truly inclusive of and welcoming to diverse individuals, stimulating innovation and idea generation. M-HOPES has developed and tested approaches that any campus could use to improve the graduate-school experience and support mental health. The holistic mentoring materials are available in online modules for anytime/anywhere access by faculty. Similarly, online “train the trainer” materials are available to enable other campuses to implement the counseling groups. The student-oriented happiness workshop is also available online for individuals and organizations. Moreover, the M-HOPES faculty and student surveys and anonymized responses have been deposited at the Inter-University Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR) to support future research with the potential to lead to even broader impacts that we cannot predict.
